The network will still run because there are people (like me) who will continue to run validators and nodes. Protocol development is another story. Ripple lacks a developer community. There are some awesome outside developers for sure, but we need a lot more, IMO.
Can you be more specific? Do you mean what happens to the $ XRP that Ripple holds?
As if Alibaba wouldn’t be HUGE for Ripple. Many businesses consider IPOs to be dead weight, btw.
I didn’t say sell to a competitor. Who exactly do you think Ripple’s competitor even is?
They bring more to the table than just money. Ripple won’t likely need *just money.* They will need someone bigger than they are to open doors that are otherwise sealed.
That’s not what I said at all. I think the public would be dead weight whereas Alibaba would open up massive opportunities for Ripple.
Ripple can be wildly successful without taking XRP with it.

I feel strongly that going public would be like carrying dead weight for Ripple. They wouldn’t be able to pivot and maneuver nearly as quickly (if at all) if random people suddenly had a say. Do you hear me @ bgarlinghouse? Lol. Not everybody gets my humor.
And I didn’t buy XRP to support Ripple either. I did it for my own potential gain.
I wouldn’t buy stock to support Ripple, lol.

No, a server can’t “compromise” the ledger creation process. And that text with the blue rectangle doesn’t say what you claim it says. This is a great overview of @ Ripple consensus if you are genuinely interested. $ XRP # xrpthestandardhttps://youtu.be/7abKUs9tYZg

XRP is a digital asset that Ripple holds and nothing more. Other people can hold this asset as well, but holders are not tied to each other in any way. I don’t know why Ripple would ever go public when they can stay private. Who wants the public to suddenly have a say? Yuck.
